The Elder Nun Kisāgotamī’s Verses
“The Victor Padumuttara,

a hundred thousand eons ago.
At that time I was born
in a certain family in Haṁsavati.
Approaching that best of men,
I went for refuge.

translated: And I listened to his Teaching,🔽which was concerned with the Four Truths,

translated: praising the nun who wore a coarse robe,
appointed her to the highest position.
Then, after experiencing a measure of joy,
having heard the nun’s qualities,
I made an offering to the Buddha
to the best of my ability and strength.
I respectfully requested that excellent sage
for that position.
Then the Sambuddha, the leader,
rejoiced in me for attaining that position.
‘In a hundred thousand eons from now,
you will be born in the Okkāka family.
You will be named Gotama by clan,
and will be a teacher in the world.
She will be the heir to the Dhamma,
the foremost in the Dhamma,
and will be called Kisāgotamī,
a disciple of the Teacher.’
Having heard that, I was delighted,
and for the rest of my life
I served the Victor,
the Leader, with requisites.
By that good deed well done,
by my intention and aspiration,
having given up my human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
In this auspicious aeon,
the kinsman of Brahmā, of great fame,🔽the best of speakers,

translated: named Kassapa, arose.🔽The lord of men, the king of Kāsi,🔽named Kikī, was the supporter
of the Great Seer
in the supreme city of Bārāṇasī.
I was his fifth daughter,
widely known by the name of Dhammaguttā.
Having heard the Dhamma of the Victor,
I requested the going forth.
Our father did not allow it,
so we remained in the house.
For twenty-thousand years,
we lived diligently.
The youthful celibate life,
the royal maidens well-nourished,
devoted to serving the Buddha,
the seven sisters were delighted.
The ascetic, the ascetic’s mother,
the nun, the one who gives to the monks,

Paṭācārā, and Kuṇḍalā,
I, and Dhammadinnā,
and Visākhā is the seventh.
Through those well-performed deeds,
and through my intentions and aspirations,
Having given up my human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
And in my last state of existence,
I was reborn in a merchant’s family.
To a poor, destitute, and ruined family,
And I went to a wealthy family.
Except for my husband, the rest
would give to the destitute.
And when I was pregnant,
I was loved by all.
When he was a young man, handsome,
tender, and well-proportioned,
I loved him as if he were my own life,

After hearing these verses,
I purified the Dhamma Eye;
Then, having understood the true Dhamma,
I went forth into homelessness.
Having gone forth in this way,
I applied myself to the Jina’s Dispensation;
Not long after that,
I attained Liberation.
I have mastery over psychic powers,
and the divine ear element;
I know the minds of others,
and the deeds of the Teacher’s instruction.
I know my past lives,
and the divine eye is purified;
Having ended all pollutants,
I am purified, stainless.
The Teacher has been served by me,
and the Buddha’s instruction has been done;
The heavy burden has been put down,
and the fetters that bound me to existence have been destroyed.
For the sake of which I went forth
from the home to the homeless life—
That goal has been reached by me,
the destruction of all fetters.
In the meaning, the Teaching, the phrasing,
and in eloquence as well,
My knowledge is spotless and pure,
through the power of the Buddha, the best.
Having taken from the top of the rubbish heap,
from the charnel ground and from the crossroads,
Then having made a patchwork robe,
I wear a coarse robe.
The Victor was pleased with that quality,
with wearing a coarse robe;
The Leader of the Saṅgha placed me
in the foremost position in this regard.
My defilements have been burned up,
I live without pollutants.
Welcome indeed it was for me,🔽…
The Buddha’s instruction has been carried out.”
